item.description:

Video Summary (Generated by AI, Editedby Human.) In this video, Xah Lee codes in Emacs Lisp to create a command that moves files or marked files to their parent directory (0:08). Here's a breakdown of the video's content: ‚Ä¢ Demonstration of manual file movement in Emacs Dired (1:02): The speaker first demonstrates the manual process of moving files in Emacs's Dired mode, which involves splitting windows, navigating directories, marking files, and using the capital R key to move them (1:02-2:08). ‚Ä¢ He emphasizes the desire to automate this process with a single command (2:12). ‚Ä¢ Introduction to Dired and File Managers (3:28): The speaker explains Dired as Emacs's directory editor, which is essentially a file manager. ‚Ä¢ He compares it to Windows File Explorer, Mac Finder, and various Linux file managers (3:28-4:32). ‚Ä¢ Getting a list of marked files (5:02): The first step in coding the command is to get a list of files that are currently marked in Dired. ‚Ä¢ If no files are marked, the file under the cursor is considered the "current file" (5:02-6:10). ‚Ä¢ The dired-get-marked-files command is used for this purpose (7:21). ‚Ä¢ Finding the parent directory (9:25): The speaker then looks for the function to find the parent directory of a given file path. ‚Ä¢ He refers to his own Emacs Lisp tutorial for this (9:32-11:58). ‚Ä¢ He identifies file-name-directory as the function to get the directory of a file and later introduces file-name-parent-directory for obtaining the parent directory specifically (52:22). ‚Ä¢ Renaming/Moving files with rename-file (12:50): The rename-file command is introduced as the way to move or rename files, following Unix conventions (13:13). ‚Ä¢ Discussion on car and cdr in Lisp (15:22): A significant portion of the video is dedicated to explaining car and cdr (pronounced "car" and "carder" by the speaker) in Lisp. ‚Ä¢ Cons Cells: He explains that Lisp lists are fundamentally built from "cons cells," which are pairs of two things (17:45). ‚Ä¢ car refers to the first part of a cons cell, and cdr refers to the second part (20:16-20:58). ‚Ä¢ Nesting for Lists: Lists are formed by nesting these cons cells (21:56). ‚Ä¢ Historical Context: The speaker provides historical context, explaining that this design originated from early Lisp machines that had hardware optimized for these two-part cells (23:41). ‚Ä¢ Modern Alternatives: He advises against using the nested car and cdr functions (like cadr or cddar) for accessing elements in a list, calling them "idiotic" and "silly" (28:18-33:11). ‚Ä¢ Instead, he recommends using higher-level functions like nth for direct access (33:37) and push and pop for stack-like operations (36:56). ‚Ä¢ List Traversal and Efficiency: He highlights that functions like length for lists are inefficient because they have to traverse each element, which is a nature of Lisp's linked list implementation (38:55). ‚Ä¢ Completing the file movement command (42:30): The speaker proceeds to finalize the Emacs Lisp command, using mapc to apply the rename-file function to each selected file, concatenating the parent directory with the file's name (55:57). ‚Ä¢ Testing the command (56:30): The command is successfully tested by moving a file to its parent directory and then moving it back (56:30-58:06). ‚Ä¢ Refinement and Future Improvements (58:11): The speaker notes that the command could be further refined by adding error checking for root directories and printing messages about the move (58:11). ‚Ä¢ He also discusses simplifying the code by removing unnecessary variables (59:23) and functional programing technique to not use any variable or constant. item.title: Why I Use Emacs for Ontologies (and How to Memorize a HUGE Knowledge Graph) [AMA #1]
item.description:
youtube

Why would an Ontology Engineer skip tools like Protege and TopBraid Composer and stick with a 'plain' text editor like Emacs? And how do you manage a complex knowledge graph with thousands of classes and properties without relying on memory alone? Those were two great questions from FredBlok4308, and I'm answering them in this video. I dive into my personal workflow, explaining the history and practical reasons for choosing a text-based approach (hint: it's a historical happy accident that was supported by it being fun, fully customizable, and better than the other options I tried). I also reveal the secret to taming graph complexity, which involves good modular design, the "use it or lose it" principle, and leveraging SPARQL queries to serve as your method for learning the vocabula. Whether you're a Semantic Web veteran or just starting with knowledge graphs, this covers the critical strategies for scaling your data modeling efforts.

item.title: Fulltext, semantic text and image search in Emacs
item.description:
youtube

I show my new org-db package for full and semantic text and image search in Emacs. This package indexes your org-files and provides several ways to search them by org-heading, full text with fts5 in sqlite, vector search for semantic search, and searching images from textual descriptions using CLIP! The whole project was "vibe-coded" with Claude Code over about 7 days. It is still in an alpha stage of development, but I have been using it for a few days now, and am pretty happy with it. https://github.com/jkitchin/org-db-v3
